Sales and excise taxes should be fair and stable, not used for social engineering or quick cash grabs—tax policy should prioritize predictable revenue over punishing legal behavior.
Illinois serves as a warning—with excessive taxes on products like JUUL and Zyn used to fund more spending instead of making tough budget decisions.
Iowa must avoid that path—by rejecting gimmicky tax hikes and focusing on responsible budgeting and spending restraint.

Property Tax Reform Stalled: Despite bipartisan support from Iowans for property tax relief, local government lobbying efforts helped weaken or block reform proposals—like the proposed 2% property tax cap—through carveouts and opposition.
Growing National Scrutiny: Iowa joins states like Texas in debating bans on taxpayer-funded lobbying, as public frustration grows over rising property taxes and perceived misuse of public funds to resist fiscal restraint.
